description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.

description: On 28th January 2020, in connection with the situation with the 2019-nCoV coronavirus, Belarusian universities will extend the vacation for Chinese students who have gone home for two weeks. Vacations for Chinese students began in late January and were supposed to end in early February. Individual students will draw up individual schedules so that there are no gaps in learning. The policy ends on 23rd of March.

description: As of 24th of August, 2020, guidelines for the organization of the educational process in educational institutions in the context of the spread of COVID-19 infection, have been published by the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Belarus. These guidelines have been developed to prevent the spread of COVID-19 infection in educational institutions of the Republic of Belarus in the 2020/2021 academic year. The document was developed in accordance with Article 23 of the Law of the Republic of Belarus On Sanitary and Epidemiological Welfare of the Population. It provides for a set of measures aimed at reducing the risk of COVID-19 infection.

description: “A new stage starts in Belarus today with mass vaccinations (Sputnik V) against COVID-19. Medical staff and teachers, will be the first to get vaccinated (tachers later on, however, see below). Vaccination will be entirely voluntary,” Belarus Health Minister Dmitry Pinevich was quoted as saying in a statement issued by his ministry and Russian health authorities.        "Now we continue vaccinating healthcare workers. We expect the next batch to arrive in the near future. Teachers will be next in line for a COVID-19 vaccine. In the first quarter of this year, we are set to release the Sputnik V vaccine under the Belarusian brand, together with Russian colleagues at the Belarus-based Belmedpreparaty pharmaceutical company,”        Unable to find evidence regarding funding so have recorded government funded for now, as vaccine is voluntary and only available to certain groups, suggesting that it couldn't be purchased privately (individually funded)

description: Vaccination of educational workers has started in the Grodno region. Employees of the Yanka Kupala State University of Grodno were among the first to receive the coronavirus vaccine, BelTA has learned. The vaccination against coronavirus in the Grodno region started in mid-January. At the first stage, more than 1.7 thousand medical workers were vaccinated. Now, according to the main health department of the Grodno Regional Executive Committee, about 3 thousand more vaccines have been delivered to the region. At the same time, both doctors and teachers receive vaccinations. The Russian vaccine Sputnik V is used.

description: The first validation series of the Sputnik V vaccine was produced in Belarus. The Russian Direct Investment Fund (RDIF), Generium JSC and Belmedpreparaty RUE, the largest Belarusian pharmaceutical company, are launching the production of the world's first registered vaccine against coronavirus, Sputnik V. Belarus became the first state after Russia to officially register Sputnik V. The marketing authorization for the vaccine was issued on December 21, 2020. In October 2020, the first foreign clinical trials of Sputnik V began in Belarus. Volunteers were vaccinated in a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trial in eight medical institutions selected as research centers. The first batch of Sputnik V was delivered to Belarus at the end of December 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

At the end of March, a mass release of a domestically produced vaccine is planned. Then the vaccination of the population will begin.

description: Certificate of vaccination will be issued at the request of a citizen planning to travel outside the country. The Ministry of Health has decided to issue a Certificate of Vaccination to citizens who have been vaccinated against COVID-19. The certificate is issued at the vaccination point on a paid basis at the request of a citizen planning to travel outside the country during the year. The document will contain information on preventive vaccinations against COVID-19, confirming vaccination-1 and vaccination-2. Citizens who do not plan to travel abroad are required to enter information on preventive vaccinations against COVID-19 in the patient's medical documents with the issuance of an extract from medical documents confirming vaccination-1 and vaccination-2. The certificate contains the following information - the name of the healthcare organization, the date of birth of the person who received preventive vaccinations against COVID-19. The certificate is filled out in Russian and English.

description: Due to the current epidemic situation in neighboring countries, on 29 October Belarus temporarily restricted entry into the country for several categories of persons coming from Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, and Ukraine via ground border checkpoints. The restrictions do not apply to drivers of vehicles, which are designed for international transportation by road, and to personnel of international trains. The border checkpoint in Minsk National Airport operates without the abovementioned restrictions.

description: "President Alexander Lukashenko reportedly ordered the partial closure of Belarus' borders with Poland, Latvia, and Lithuania on (and from) Thursday, October 29, [...]. The extent of the new restrictions was not clear from Lukashenko's announcement, in which he claimed they had been introduced to reduce the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). However, Polish and Lithuanian authorities stated that foreign nationals had been barred from entering Belarus via their border crossings since 16:00 (local time), with only Belarusian nationals and freight traffic being permitted to cross the border. Lithuanian guards later reported that vehicles had also been prevented from crossing the border from the Belarus side. [...]    To better facilitate arrival, foreign nationals are encouraged to carry proof of a negative result for COVID-19 issued no more than 48 hours prior to departure using a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test.        "From October 29, 2020, all persons arriving in Belarus must self-isolate for 10 days upon arrival. This policy does not apply to persons arriving from the following countries / regions: Austria, Albania, China, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Latvia, Monaco, Montenegro, Norway, Serbia, and Spain"

description: Continuing from 20 December, the government of Belarus has had exit controls at its land borders. Land borders are currently closed to U.S. citizens.     Flights continue to operate in and out of Minsk National Airport as normal. Incoming from foreign countries must quarantine.

description:
MINSK, 14 April (BelTA) - The Healthcare Ministry has published the information on the number of COVID-19 cases by region, Belarus Deputy Healthcare Minister Yelena Bogdan said during a live stream on the YouTube channel of the National Press Center,  BelTA has learned.

As of 8 a.m., there were 3,281 coronavirus cases in the country: 73 cases in Brest Oblast, 848 in Vitebsk Oblast, 106 in Gomel Oblast, 53 in Grodno Oblast, 1691 in the city of Minsk, 359 in Minsk Oblast and 151 in Mogilev Oblast.

Despite the fact that some regions, including Brest Oblast and Grodno Oblast have fewer cases, people should not ignore the measures recommended by the Healthcare Ministry. “First of all, these include keeping physical distance, hand washing and self-isolation,” Yelena Bogdan said.

As of 14 April, 71,875 tests for coronavirus infection were performed in Belarus. Seventeen laboratories are involved in testing.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: Reported on 1 June - the epidemiological situation remains serious. It is very difficult to make credible analysis, since official statistics released by the Government are limited and does not look reliable. The epidemiological curve has been on a plateau for a month, with an average number of new cases around 900 daily. The number of daily deaths has been stable on 4 - 5. This epi trend is difficult to explain other than that it may not reflect the real situation.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Ministry of Health clarified the first and second levels of contact. The corresponding resolution of the Ministry of Health No. 81 of October 2, 2020 was published on the National Legal Internet Portal , BelTA informs. It will come infor effect on 8 October. Level 1 contacts include people who have been in close contact with a person with COVID-19 infection 4 days before and 10 days after they show symptoms of the disease. These are also people who have been in contact with an asymptomatic carrier 4 days before and 10 days after the date of collection of the material for testing for this infection. Second-level contacts include children under the age of 10 attending kindergarten or school, if they had possible contact with a person with COVID-19 within 4 days before and 10 days after the onset of symptoms of the disease. The same applies to cases where children communicated with an asymptomatic carrier. Close contact is considered to be contact for at least 15 minutes at a distance of less than 1 m without the use of personal respiratory protection. Possible - at a distance of 1 m to 2 m without the use of personal protective equipment for the respiratory system.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: "Monitoring of the epidemiology of COVID-19 cases and their contacts is undertaken by the Sanitary and Epidemiology Service, subordinate to the Ministry of Health.  Contact tracing is conducted by medical personnel from the sanitary epidemiological service with involvement of the Ministry of Internal Affairs. By 22 March more than 23,000 contacts. Each case is viewed as a cluster and all contracts are traced."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: According to a decree of National Government of Belarus from 30 October, 2020, the following categories of citizens will be subject to compulsory medical examination for the presence of COVID-19 infection  persons having a COVID-19 infection; related to first-level contacts with persons with COVID-19 infection or second-level contacts with persons with COVID-19 infection, in the presence of one or more respiratory symptoms in the event that such citizens are children under the age of 10 and attend a preschool or general secondary education; persons subject to hospitalization for the provision of planned medical care in inpatient conditions; medical workers when they provide medical assistance to persons with COVID-19 infection. In addition, the document establishes a list of symptoms that citizens have, which are the basis for compulsory medical examination of these citizens for COVID-19 infection in the presence of an epidemiological history of the possibility of contracting this infection.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of June 15, 2021, the results of a study of post-infectious immunity were obtained in 99.6% of participants, post-vaccination immunity - in 97.4% of participants who indicated in the questionnaire that they were vaccinated against covid-19 with the gam-covid-vac vaccine (sputnik v). according to preliminary data, post-infectious seropositivity to the sars-cov-2 virus among the population of the republic of Belarus was 38.4% and ranged from 34.1% in the Minsk region to 42.1% in the Grodno region (fig).

description: As of 29th of June, the municipal executive announces that, in Grodno, Belarus, a module for contactless collection of tests on COVID-19 began to work. A modular laboratory for the non-contact collection of biomaterials for coronavirus began to work in Grodno. The module, equipped on the basis of a standard sea container, was installed at the entrance of the Grodno Regional Infectious Diseases Clinical Hospital. Analyzes here on a paid basis will be able to pass those who plan to go abroad. The main feature of the module is the lack of direct contacts.

description:
On April 3, Belarusian Healthcare Ministry revises procedure for observing contacts of COVID-19 patients.

The ministry has also decided to hospitalize second-tier contacts and examine them for COVID-19 if they demonstrate symptoms of an acute respiratory disease. If examination results are negative and their health does not get worse, they will be discharged for consequent out-patient treatment.

Besides, the Healthcare Ministry has decided in favor of testing all patients with moderate pneumonia and severe pneumonia for COVID-19. These measures are designed to detect patients with the coronavirus pneumonia as best as possible.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Confirmed contact to a person infected with COVID-19

description: In a Ministry of Health briefing given on 10 April it was clarified that Belarus did not plan any postponement of conscription. According to Elena Bogdan, the Deputy Minister of Health, 8-10% of COVID-19 tests give positive results, and more than 65,000 COVID-19 tests are currently available in Belarus. It was also reported that 10 out of 169 recovered COVID-19 patients had agreed to become the donors of isoimmune blood plasma: "This is a new scientific direction for the RSPC of Transfusiology and Medical Biotechnologies. We will be developing a new method of treating the most severe cases of coronavirus infection with isoimmune plasma of the recovered patients".
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Reported on 1 June - an average of 12.000 - 13.000 tests are conducted daily with a positivity rate of 6.9%  8% lately. Age or geographical distribution of cases is not available. The total number of beds in the country is around 100.000 and occupancy rate with COVID-19 patients was maximum 18% (as per the MoH) at once. Total number of ventilation machines in the country is 2500 and maximum 13% of them were used for COVID-19 patients at once

description: In the 3rd of September, 2020, the executives of municipal government of Minsk city, belarus, reported that testing for COVID-19 is now available at Minsk National Airport. Currently, test by ELISA  enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay  is available. Anyone can be tested  arriving and departing passengers, aviation personnel, visitors and employees of the airport and other organizations . The laboratory is open Monday to Friday from 9.00 to 18.00. A transition to a round-the-clock operating mode is planned for next month. To be tested, a passport and a document confirming payment must be provided.

description:
"The Ministry of Health will determine the list of laboratories for conducting research for COVID-19 infection with the transfer of the results to the Traveling without COVID-19 system. This is provided by the order of the Prime Minister of the Republic of Belarus dated March 1, 2021 No. 44r. The document was adopted in order to ensure the provision of services in the republic to individuals travelling through the territory of the Eurasian Economic Union by air using the mobile application Traveling without COVID-19. The Ministry of Health also needs to ensure interaction with the Republican Unitary Enterprise National Center for Electronic Services on issues of data transfer to the Traveling without COVID-19 system.

The Ministry of Transport and Communications was instructed to ensure interaction with the Ministry of Health when organizing the movement of persons through air checkpoints when they present negative results of tests for COVID-19 infection using the specified mobile application."

description: This may be one reason Belarus also outperformed most of Europe in terms of mass testing during the first four months of the pandemic. While many countries were reluctant to carry out extensive testing, according to the state-owned news agency BelTA, testing in Belarus started as early as 23 January. Most kits were donated or purchased from China and Russia using government funds and donations from companies and ordinary citizens. The country stepped up testing in early April, developing its own rapid testing kits and switching to the use of domestically produced reagents for polymerase chain reaction testing in May. According to government information, there are now 32 laboratories processing samples across the country and testing is widespread in hospitals as well as among GPs.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: PCR and/or antigen tests are available within 72 hours. Tests can be obtained at the airport or health clinics in a number of cities. The deputy chief doctor also touched upon the use of rapid antibody tests. According to Irina Glinskaya, the first batch has been received and already tested.  We have already seen how rapid tests work both in the laboratory and the hospital. This week, we expect the delivery of a new batch

description: On May 6 it was announced that disinfection of ambulances and medical institutions is carried out in Minsk, Belarus. Since February 2020, several stations have been operation to disinfect ambulances, vehicles that deliver medical personnel to work and home, as well as cars of private individuals transporting people with infectious diseases. The emphasis in the treatment of medical institutions is placed on common areas - corridors, elevators, staircases, bathrooms. Medical disinfectants are also used in offices, to clean tables, chairs, changing tables, washbasins, cabinets, and doors.

In the near future, there will be another 25 pieces. A reserve of personal protective equipment and disinfection has also been created.

description: On June 17, 2020, in Belarus, the Ministry of Health published recommendations for the prevention of COVID-19 in health resort organizations/sanatoriums. Recommendations include breaks between arrivals of vacationers for general cleaning and disinfection. If the institution has its own transport, which provides services to vacationers (transfer, excursions), it should be sanitized after use. It is necessary to organize daily wet cleaning of premises using household detergents or disinfectants with the treatment of all surfaces. Surfaces include door handles, handrails, elevator buttons, tables, chairs, other pieces of furniture, sanitary equipment, telephones, office equipment panels and other items that people touch. Daily disinfection is also necessary in regards to the surfaces of equipment and elements of small architectural forms on the street (examples include the gym, sports grounds, gazebos, benches, beach equipment). It is recommended to ventilate the premises regularly. Dispensers with an antiseptic (disinfectant) hand sanitizer (preferably alcohol-based) should be regularly maintained. After appointments for medical services or procedures, it is necessary to disinfect the surfaces and ventilate the room.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of 14th of July, 2020, the Ministry of Health of Belarus, has developed recommendations to prevent the spread of respiratory infections  including COVID-19  when voting, includingthe recommendation to arrange for regular processing  at least 6 times during election day  with disinfectants of door handles, railings, surfaces in voting booths, tables and other contact surfaces. On days of early voting, to ensure that the cleaning of the premises where voting takes place is carried out during the break from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m..
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: In Belarus on March 18, 2020 the Ministry of transport restricted rest and food points for drivers and refuelling of vehicles for carriers passing through the territory of the Republic of Belarus. Stop points should be equipped with personal protective equipment. The restrictions will take effect on March 19. UPDATE: On March 26, 2020 it was announced that interstate drivers going in transit via Belarus, including from Russia to the EU and Ukraine, should use only the major thoroughfares that have rest areas where drivers can rest, eat and refuel. Interstate drivers going through Belarus should use the least time track and leave Belarus the next day. This requirement does not apply if a driver experiences a road accident or a vehicle breakdown, or has to perform unloading/transloading operations, or to replace their vehicle provided this is envisaged by their haulage contract and is indicated in transportation documents. In this case drivers are allowed to exit onto other roads. These operations should be done as fast as possible.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Starting in the last week March/ first week April, 2020, the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Belarus has posted the recommendations which include:  - Do not go out of the house unless it is particularly necessary (going to work, buying food and medicines, receiving medical and other vital services).  - Do not leave home to visit places that are not vital (libraries, museums, cinemas, theaters, and other public places). Children may only go out with the family. Arrange to walk pets alone.  - Refrain from attending classes in clubs, sports clubs, gyms, even with a minimum number of participants. In case you continue sports activities, make sure that the group size does not exceed 5 people and that a distance of 1.5-2 m between people is maintained during the activities.  - Communicate with others remotely by means of communication. Do not visit or host friends and family members who do not live with you.  - The following measures can be used to reduce the need to leave the house: remote work, video calls and conference calls; Each employer must ensure that a distance of 1-1.5 meters between employees' workplaces, personal hygiene and environmental (room) hygiene is maintained;  - Choose delivery services - only to the doorstep of the apartment (house, office);  - If you go out of the house in situations where it is necessary (see point 1), it is necessary to reduce contact with other people and keep a 1.5 - 2 meter distance from each other.    Web sources:
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 16, 2020,hotlines for the prevention and treatment of coronavirus infection operate in the Minsk region of Belarus. Callers can consult doctors about symptoms, treatment, clarify which specialist they should contact and when, and they can also learn about preventative measures. The regional hotline is 8 (017) 517-20-25 and it is open from Monday to Friday from 8.00 to 17.00. Hotlines in hospitals are available 24/7, on weekends and holidays. Consultations are given by the Borisov maternity hospital, the Zhodino central city hospital, as well as in Berezinskaya, Borisovskaya, Vileika, Volozhinskaya, Dzerzhinskaya, Kletskaya, Kopylskaya, Krupskaya, Logoiskaya, Lyubanskaya, Maryinogorskaya, Minsk, Molodechnenskaya, Myadelskaya, Nesvizhskaya, Slutskaya, Smolevichskaya Soligorsk, Starodorozhskaya, Stolbtsovskaya, Uzdenskaya and Chervenskaya central regional hospitals. There is also a hotline at the Republican Center for Hygiene, Epidemiology and Public Health in Belarus which accepts calls on weekdays from 8.30 to 13.00 and from 13.30 to 18.00. For residents of Minsk on these issues, a hotline is open at the Minsk Infectious Diseases Hospital at +375 (17) 334-34-68 from 8.30 to 15.00. Youth hotlines are open from Monday to Saturday from 9.00 to 18.00: in Brest, Vitebsk, Gomel, Grodno, Mogilev. In large cities of the Minsk region, such lines operate in Soligorsk, Slutsk, and Molodechno. Also in Minsk, a hotline specifically offers information assistance to the elderly.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: As for the workers of the Great Stone, about 80 people are waiting for the return of Minsk - these are workers who were also not in quarantine zones. All of them will hold a two-week paid quarantine in their apartments, as additional safety measures for employees have been introduced in the park. The park administration is completing the purchase of all necessary facilities for sanitation of the territory. Contact has been made with the Smolevichi District Hospital in order to better organize all measures to protect the health of employees in the manner of consulting assistance. In addition, in the first residential building on the territory of the park a feldsher point has already been commissioned. Now there is always a medical officer.

description: On March 25, Belarus introduced a mandatory 14 day self-isolation (quarantine) for all travelers, including Belarus citizens, who arrived from countries listed as epidemiologically dangerous (169 countries in total). UPDATE: On March 31, the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Belarus defined a set of rules for self-isolation for travelers arriving from countries where cases of infection are registered. These rules state that persons who are in self-isolation: must not leave their place of residence (or stay), including visiting places of work (study), shops, shopping centers, catering facilities, sports, exhibition and concert halls, cinemas, train stations and other places of mass stay of people, except in cases of extreme necessity; must use the services of online stores to purchase goods, excluding direct contact with the persons who delivered the goods; must perform a number of hygiene measures (wash hands thoroughly with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, or use an antiseptic to treat hands; use disposable handkerchiefs or napkins with subsequent disposal in a closed trash can or plastic bag, etc.); in case of a deterioration in health (an increase in body temperature of 370C and above, the appearance of coughing, shortness of breath), they should contact an ambulance by calling 103 or by SMS.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Belarusian government has set self-isolation rules for those who needs to follow them. Self-isolation rules apply to citizens of Belarus and foreigners who test positive for COVID-19, as well as first- and second-level contacts. First-level contacts need to self-isolate for 14 days following the date of the last contact with the infected, second-level contacts ï¿½ with the appearance of symptoms (cough, sore throat, shortness of breath, fever). The doctor may decide on prolonging self-isolation time.If the person breaks the self-isolation rules, he or she gets 50% of sick pay envisaged by the law.Those violating the self-isolation rules will be fined.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

 UPDATE: The conditions of quarantine have changed, instead of mandatory quarantine in government facilities, from April 10 it is a home quarantine with a punishment for violation
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: Belarus, on February 27. The Ministry of health enforces quarantine COVID-19 patients and their first-level contacts in medical facilities. The application of this practice began with the identification of the first infected person. UPDATE: On April 9 it was announced that citizens of Belarus, foreigners and stateless persons should be placed on self-isolation in Belarus if they have a COVID-19 infection; if they relate to contacts: of the first level with persons with COVID-19 infection - within 14 calendar days from the date of the last contact; second level with persons with COVID-19 infection, in the presence of one or more respiratory symptoms - for the period of the indicated symptoms. The Ministry of Health can establish which level of contacts this or that person belongs to if they arrived in Belarus from countries in which cases of COVID-19 infection are registered, within 14 calendar days from the date of arrival. Those who go to self-isolation will be given a requirement to comply with the rules. For this period, people will be issued a certificate of incapacity for work if they, as well as themselves, pay compulsory insurance premiums. If a person violates the requirements for self-isolation, then temporary disability benefits will be assigned in the amount of 50 percent of what is required by law. The periods of stay of citizens in self-isolation can be extended by the decision of doctors. Violators face fines and liability, including to a criminal level. Those in self-isolation are required to not leave their place of residence and are only allowed to go to the nearest grocery store or pharmacy, as well as take out the trash. When leaving the living quarters in cases of extreme necessity, they must use a mask.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: In Belarus, The Government of Belarus has issued a Regulation No. 208 of 8 April 2020 which introduces additional restrictive measures. This document shall enter into force on 10 April 2020. The new regulation notably requires that self-isolation requirements shall also be applicable to drivers after completion of international road transport of goods in the territory of Belarus. The regulation also requires that drivers performing international road transport operations across the territory of Belarus, must have personal protective equipment  medical masks, gloves  on board and use them when they leave the cabin
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Belarus, on February 27, 2020. The Ministry of health enforces quarantine COVID-19 patients and their first-level contacts in medical facilities. The application of this practice began with the identification of the first infected person.

UPDATE: The Ministry of Health have revised the conditions for monitoring of people who are considered first-level contacts and they can now remain in self-isolation at home. The conditions were revised since some citizens did not give consent to hospitalization for 14 days because they met all needed conditions for self-isolation at home. Now, first-level contacts will be at home on self-isolation under the supervision of a local therapist. Testing of first-level contacts will be carried out on the first, seventh, and 12-13 day. UPDATE: The Ministry of Health have revised the conditions for monitoring of people who are considered first-level contacts and they can now remain in self-isolation at home. The conditions were revised since some citizens did not give consent to hospitalization for 14 days because they met all needed conditions for self-isolation at home. compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: In Belarus, on April 14, Ministry of Health published a clarification on mandatory measures to adhere to when under self-isolation  The self-isolation regime must be observed for 14 days and the following rules needs to be followed  - Do not visit the place of work   study, as well as places of mass stay of people  shops, cafes, shopping centers and others ; - ensure the delivery of products, essentials, excluding direct contact with the person who delivered the necessary, it is advisable to carry out the calculation using a bank card, and not cash; - limit as much as possible any contacts, including with family members living with you in the same apartment  stay in a separate room, in the absence of a separate room - ensure a distance of at least 1.5 m from other family members; - wash hands with soap thoroughly and for at least 20 seconds, not forgetting about the area between the fingers, around the nails, cuticles and thumb. You can use an antiseptic to handle your hands; - as often as possible to ventilate the room where you are, carry out wet cleaning in the room, paying particular attention to the processing of door handles, furniture, telephones, control panels, computer keyboards, mice and other gadgets, sanitary equipment and other items; - use disposable handkerchiefs or wipes, and then dispose of them in a closed garbage container or plastic bag.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Belarus, on February 27. The Ministry of health enforces quarantine COVID-19 patients and their first-level contacts in medical facilities. The application of this practice began with the identification of the first infected person. UPDATE: On April 22 the enforcement of quarantine policies in Belarus was strengthened. Police officers together with representatives of the epidemiological service enforce self-isolation and undertake visits to homes of people in self-isolation, which include sick people, the first-level contacts (they are on a sick leave under medical supervision) and also second-level contacts that are showing acute respiratory disease symptoms.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: Belarus, on May 8, The Ministry of Health decided on the established procedure for extending and reducing the length of stay of citizens in self-isolation. This is provided for by the decree of the Ministry No. 49 of May 8, 2020. The terms of self-isolation for citizens of Belarus, foreign citizens and stateless persons are extended if, when a laboratory test of biological material is repeated, a positive result on COVID-19 is obtained from a person with this infection or a first-level contact. This also applies to cases where on the last day of the established period of self-isolation the medical examination of a first-level contact according to COVID-19 has not been completed
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 11, 2020, changes were made to the list of countries upon arrival from which it is necessary to be in self-isolation for 14 days in Belarus. Of the 169 countries that were included in the list in March, 37 countries that have improved their epidemiological situation are excluded. These are as follows: Austria, Albania, Belgium, Bulgaria, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Hungary, Germany, Greece, Denmark, Ireland, Iceland, Spain, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Malta, Moldova, Monaco, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, North Macedonia, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Finland, France, Croatia, Montenegro, Czech Republic, Switzerland, Sweden, Estonia and China. People who came from these countries are not required to be in self-isolation for 14 days from the date of arrival in Belarus. At the same time, foreigners arriving in Belarus must have a negative PCR result when crossing the border - a study performed no later than two days before the date of crossing the border.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On June 17, 2020, it was announced that the Ministry of Health in Belarus recommends that customers arriving to a sanatorium who are found to have a high temperature are quarantined at the sanatorium. It is recommended to accept citizens arriving from abroad if there is information (certificate) about the lack of contact with a person infected with COVID-19 within the last 14 days before the date of departure and a negative laboratory test for COVID-19 infection (it must be carried out no later than two days before arrival).

description: The isolation period is only 10 days for those arriving from countries with an unfavorable epidemic situation, and for those who are established as first-level contact with infected COVID-19. On October 13, 2020, it was announced that the list of persons who are not subject to the 10 day self-isolation upon arrival in Belarus from countries in which cases of COVID-19 are registered has been expanded. These are the heads and members of official delegations; those who travel through Belarus in transit and leave the country within 24 hours; arrived from business trips; persons who transport stem cells, organs for transplantation. Foreigners who arrived from countries not included by the Ministry of Health on the list of countries where COVID-19 cases are registered must present a negative COVID-19 test when entering Belarus, performed no later than 72 hours before the date of crossing the border. This does not apply to foreigners and stateless persons permanently residing in Belarus. Also, citizens in self-isolation are allowed, in case of emergency, to visit a health care organization to receive emergency and (or) emergency medical care. Quarantine still applies to other countries previously listed.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: The isolation period is only 10 days for those arriving from countries with an unfavorable epidemic situation, and for those who are established as first-level contact with infected COVID-19. On October 13, 2020 it was announced that the list of persons who are not subject to the 10 day self-isolation upon arrival in Belarus from countries in which cases of COVID-19 are registered has been expanded. These are the heads and members of official delegations; those who travel through Belarus in transit and leave the country within 24 hours; arrived from business trips; persons who transport stem cells, organs for transplantation. Foreigners who arrived from countries not included by the Ministry of Health on the list of countries where COVID-19 cases are registered must present a negative COVID-19 test when entering Belarus, performed no later than 72 hours before the date of crossing the border. This does not apply to foreigners and stateless persons permanently residing in Belarus. Also, citizens in self-isolation are allowed, in case of emergency, to visit a health care organization to receive emergency and (or) emergency medical care. Quarantine still applies to other countries previously listed. UPDATE: The Ministry of Health updated the list of countries in which cases of infection with COVID-19 are registered. Since October 21, 2020 the list includes 28 countries that were previously excluded from it. These are France, Belgium, Luxembourg, Moldova, United States of America, Lebanon, Netherlands, Iceland, Czech Republic, United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Romania, North Macedonia, Ireland, Portugal, Slovenia, Slovakia, Tunisia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Switzerland, Poland, Lithuania, Sweden, Denmark, Liechtenstein, Malta, Bulgaria and Canada. People arriving from these countries are required to be in self-isolation for 10 calendar days after arriving in Belarus. Quarantine also still applies to other countries previously listed. UPDATE: The Ministry of Health updated the list of countries in which cases of infection with COVID-19 are registered. Since October 21, the list includes 28 countries that were previously excluded from it. These are France, Belgium, Luxembourg, Moldova, United States of America, Lebanon, Netherlands, Iceland, Czech Republic, United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Romania, North Macedonia, Ireland, Portugal, Slovenia, Slovakia, Tunisia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Switzerland, Poland, Lithuania, Sweden, Denmark, Liechtenstein, Malta, Bulgaria and Canada. People arriving from these countries are required to be in self-isolation for 10 calendar days after arriving in Belarus. Quarantine also still applies to other countries previously listed.

The ban is valid until June 31, 2020

description: On 18 August, 2020, the Minsk City Executive Committee of Belarus, announced that managers of facilities of all forms hotel business, trade, public catering, social services, organizations providing postal services, as well as city support services and other organizations must organize daily monitoring of temperature amongst their employees. Temperature of all staff shall be taken before the start of a shift and be noted down. Any person with high temperature shall not start their shift. Observance of social distancing: apply markings for a safe distance between consumers of at least 1.5 m and post information about the need to maintain a safe distance, shall be applied as well. In addition, it is important to ensure the availability and supply of detergents and disinfectants, personal respiratory protection equipment and gloves, and dispensers for treating hands with antiseptics

description: On the 19th of October, 2020, the Ministry of Health pf Belarus approves methodological recommendations for the prevention of coronavirus infection (COVID-19). The Ministry of Health approved guidelines for the prevention of coronavirus infection (COVID-19). They are intended for workers and visitors of commercial and non-profit organizations, enterprises, and institutions, as well as individual entrepreneurs, and are aimed at reducing the risks of the spread of infection and maintaining health in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic. These recommendations can be used in the activities of interested organizations of all forms of ownership. description: On January 8, 2021, decree No. 512 On Amendments to the Decree of the President of the Republic of Belarus entered into force, which amended paragraph 14 of Decree No. 143 On Supporting the Economy, which regulates labor relations. Including an innovation for workers who are already sick; It is the right of the employer to release a person from work for up to three calendar days in total for health reasons without issuing a sick leave. The decree also provides for such a measure as the right of the employer to declare a downtime caused by the unfavorable impact of the epidemiological situation on the activities of the organization, without limiting the total duration during the calendar year (the limit of 6 months has been removed).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: Non-Essential Businesses
institution_status: This type of business ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with no conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On January 8, 2021, decree No. 512 On Amendments to the Decree of the President of the Republic of Belarus entered into force, which amended paragraph 14 of Decree No. 143 On Supporting the Economy, which regulates labor relations. These are socio-economic measures to support employees and organizations during an unfavorable epidemiological situation. In particular, to prevent the spread of coronavirus infection and ensure the continuous operation of the organization, the employer has the right to create a so-called replacement labor reserve. The employer will be able to initiate, with the consent of the employee, a vacation to find him. The duration of the vacation is not limited, but the employer determines the place where the employee will be. It can be a sanatorium, hotel, boarding house. that for this period the employee will have a salary not lower than the wage rate (wage salary). The collective bargaining agreement may increase the amount of saved earnings , - said Valentina Maslovskaya.

Such measures may be required by different employers, but they are especially relevant for organizations with a continuous production process. Valentina Maslovskaya stressed that this self-isolation mechanism applies to healthy workers - in order to prevent the spread of infection."
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
The Ministry of Health of the Republic of Belarus recommends working from home where possible and instituting increased sanitisation procedures:
2.1.2. If possible and with the written consent of the employee, the organization of remote work, the use of a flexible work schedule. The maximum possible number of employees should be transferred to remote work in compliance with the recommended measures." 
"It is recommended to carry out disinfection using disinfectants approved for use for these purposes by the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Belarus, according to a regime effective against viruses, in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions (hereinafter -  disinfectants) of the contact surfaces of vehicles that transport workers after each trip.  A similar procedure is applied when carrying out business trips in the Republic of Belarus.
2.1.10. It is advisable to preferentially use non-contact door openers, light switches, and sanitary equipment.   
2.1.11. Providing a minimum monthly supply of disinfectants and antiseptics, protective equipment; constant control over the timely replenishment of stocks and compliance with the standards for the provision of workers with protective equipment.  
2.1.12. Ensuring a safe drinking regime for workers (equipping with drinking water coolers and disposable cups, or bottled water in a small package).   
2.1.13. Allocation, if necessary, of separate rooms for storing personal and work clothes of employees.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Use of protective equipment: 1) Provision of workers in the workplace with a stock of masks (based on the duration of the working shift and the frequency of changing masks at least once every 2 hours); 2) Ensuring control over the correct use of protective equipment by employees. 
When using disposable and reusable masks, certain rules must be observed in accordance with Appendix 1 to these guidelines.
A set of measures for social distancing: 1) restriction of contacts between the teams of individual structural divisions of the organization that are not connected by common tasks and production processes; 2) the division of the start and end time of working shifts (working time) into several consecutive periods with the condition that the periods between the start/end of different shifts should be sufficient for all employees to pass through the entrance/ exit to the organization, etc.; 3) separation of work flows and separation of team members by placing employees on different floors, in separate offices, organizing work in several shifts; 4) observing a distance of at least 1-1.5 meters between the workers' workplaces; 5) organization of the installation of physical barriers in customer service areas – transparent plastic protection, through window, etc., organization of a distance of at least 1-1.5 meters between customers (buyers) while waiting for the release of goods, services; 6) using contactless greeting methods.

description: Belarus, May 21, Each deputy must take control of boarding houses for the elderly and disabled in his district. This was announced today at a meeting of the House of Representatives by its chairman Vladimir Andreichenko. A number of measures have been taken to minimize the spread of infection in social institutions for the elderly and disabled. Boarding houses are transferred to complete isolation, the staff works on a rotational basis, daily medical monitoring is carried out, a stock of personal protective equipment and medicines has been accumulated. They are bought, among other things, by the efforts of parliamentarians.  This work should be continued together with the executive authorities. I believe that every deputy should take control of boarding houses located in his constituency,  Vladimir Andreichenko emphasized.

description: On June 20, 2020 it was announced that swimming is limited in 10 recreation areas in Belarus. In six of these recreational zones, which are located in the Gomel region, children are not allowed to swim. Both adults and children are not allowed to swim in the remaining four recreation zones which are located in the Mogilev region. Swimming is prohibited for everyone in the following 2 recreation areas: Grebenevskoye and Pechersky reservoirs in Mogilev.

description: On April 8, 2020, the Ministry of Health and the Minsk City Executive Committee posted social distancing policies, including:  - to walk your pets alone   - elevators should be used alone  - in a private car, there must be only family members living in the same house in the cabin. (An exception is the need to accompany a person in an emergency situation)  - face masks were made mandatory in all enclosed public spaces.   - the legal requirements for business owners to maintain physical distance for customers (of at least 1.5m and post information about the need to maintain a safe distance)  - refrain from attending classes in clubs, sports clubs, gyms, even with a minimum number of participants. In case you continue sports activities, make sure that the group size does not exceed 5 people.

description:
Belarus, May 12, Festivities dedicated to the 500th anniversary of the founding of the Zhirovichi Monastery have been postponed to a later date

Update: Zhirovichi is celebrating the anniversaries that are important for the entire Eastern Orthodox community - the 550th anniversary of the appearance of the Icon of the Mother of God and the 500th anniversary of the founding of the Holy Dormition Stavropegic Monastery, BelTA reports. The celebration will be low-key. An all-night vigil on 19 May will be followed by a Divine Liturgy for the parish in the morning. All the services will be held in accordance with safety rules and with observance of social distancing. UPDATE: the 550th anniversary of the appearance of the Icon of the Mother of God and the 500th anniversary of the founding of the Holy Dormition Stavropegic Monastery will be celebrated on May 19

description:
Recommendations on social distancing during the registration of cases of COVID-19 infection: 
1) refrain from attending classes in circles, sports clubs, and gyms, even with a minimum number of participants. When,  if you are continuing sports activities, make sure that the size of the group  does not exceed 5 people and during classes, a distance of 1.5-2 m is observed  between people

description:
On May 13, the Belarusian railway extends the validity of the new spacious seating plan in trains with numbered seats until June 15 inclusive. The seating plan according to the new scheme was introduced by the Belarusian Railways from April 15 for passengers to maintain the necessary social distance in compartment, reserved seats and in cars with seats

Update: On May 27, The Belarusian Railway has extended the validity of the new seating plan for trains with numbered seats until July 1, 2020 UPDATE: The original date was set to June 15, but it was extended until July 1.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Reported on 1 June - At a meeting with the Health Minister, it was mentioned that tests are planned to be increased up to 20.000 on a daily basis. Further, that the health system is functioning stably and without interruptions.  If it is seen that the system approaches its limit, introduction of physical distancing measures will be considered, but not before.  The Minister added that a stabilization of the epi situation has been seen recently and even a decrease of new cases in Minsk and Vitebsk region. Lastly, the Minister said the situation is carefully monitored and under control.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Belarus, on June 3, Minsk National Airport asks passengers to use protective masks when entering the terminal and before leaving the airport, to adhere to other preventive measures such as hand hygiene, physical distancing of 1.5m and respiratory etiquette. description: Since June 5th, 2020, intervals of public transport have been decreased during rush hours in Minsk, Belarus. In the morning rush hours, the number of buses on routes No. 115E, 127, 144C, 159 was increased by 1 unit per each, from 6:30 to 8:30 and from 17:00 to 19:00 the interval of train traffic was reduced from 3 minutes to 2.5 minutes on both the first and second line of the metro line.

description: In Belarus, on June 5, In an interview with the media house BelTA - Inna Karaban, deputy head of the Department of Hygiene, Epidemiology and Prevention, said that Belarusians should continue to observe distance measures and wear masks in crowded places  metro, shops, public transport, banks, etc.  and observe measures of social distance. In the open air  for example, in parks, squares , where it is possible to socially distance oneself, wearing masks is inappropriate, she further stated.

description: In Belarus, on June 11, Minister of Health reminded the population about basic principles  the need to wash hands, to some extent observe social distance, to protect oneself and the most vulnerable groups of citizens - the elderly and people with chronic diseases. Further, the Ministry of Health stated that they expect the appearance of a vaccine from COVID-19 for wide clinical use no earlier than next year. Therefore, recommendations on the observance of security measures by the population remain valid.

description: Starting on June 13th, 2020, the subway train interval will be reduced by one minute on weekends in Minsk, Belarus. As such, more trains will go on both lines of the subway from 7:00 to 20:00 every weekend and as necessary, rolling stock will be added to certain routes. Currently, the interval of train traffic in the specified period is from 5 to 6 minutes on the 1st line on Saturday and from 6.5 to 7.5 minutes on Sunday; on the 2nd line - from 6 to 6.5 minutes on Saturday and from 6.5 to 7 minutes on Sunday.

description: On June 17 in Belarus, 2020, the Ministry of Health published recommendations for the prevention of COVID-19 in health resort organizations/sanatoriums. Recommendations include one-time arrival of vacationers and the use of signal markings ad the check-in counter which informs vacationers that they must be distanced at the counter during their check-in and check-out. In canteens, tables must be arranged to be placed at least at a 1.5-2 m distance from each other. It is recommended to reduce the number of people simultaneously in the dining room. When organizing food through the distribution line, the operation of a buffet or a store on the floor, signal markings should be applied about the need to maintain a distance. If the organization has its own beach, it is recommended to place beach equipment with a distance of at least 1.5-2 m from each other. In regards to the gym, it is necessary to ensure the distance between the guests, including by arranging the equipment, is at least 1.5-2 m. If the institution has its own transport, which provides services to vacationers (transfer, excursions), it should be filled with respect to distance.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 18 August, 2020, the Minsk City Executive Committee of Belarus, announced that managers of facilities of all forms hotel business, trade, public catering, social services, organizations providing postal services, as well as city support services and other organizations must organize daily monitoring of temperature amongst their employees. Temperature of all staff shall be taken before the start of a shift and be noted down. Any person with high temperature shall not start their shift. Observance of social distancing: apply markings for a safe distance between consumers of at least 1.5 m and post information about the need to maintain a safe distance, shall be applied as well. In addition, it is important to ensure the availability and supply of detergents and disinfectants, personal respiratory protection equipment and gloves, and dispensers for treating hands with antiseptics
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: As of 24th of August, 2020, guidelines for the organization of the educational process in educational institutions in the context of the spread of COVID-19 infection, have been published by the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Belarus. These guidelines have been developed to prevent the spread of COVID-19 infection in educational institutions of the Republic of Belarus in the 2020/2021 academic year. The document was developed in accordance with Article 23 of the Law of the Republic of Belarus On Sanitary and Epidemiological Welfare of the Population. It provides for a set of measures aimed at reducing the risk of COVID-19 infection.

description: On September 14, 2020, in Minsk, Belarus, it was announced that in order to prevent a worsening of the situation with the incidence of acute respiratory infections (ARI), including COVID-19, simple rules must be followed: use personal protective equipment for the respiratory system in public places, change the mask (preferably a medical disposable) every 2 hours; wash hands with soap and water as often as possible, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer; ventilate the premises as often as possible and carry out wet cleaning; observe respiratory etiquette.

description: On September 25, 2020, it was announced in Belarus that the Ministry of Health recommends the correct use of a mask to protect against infections. Before putting on the mask, you must treat your hands with an antiseptic (disinfectant) agent or wash them with soap. Then, holding the mask by the ties or elastic bands, you need to bring it close to your face with the white side inward and fix it. Respiratory etiquette is important.

description: On 5 November, Mogilev became the first city in Belarus to introduce compulsory use of facial masks in public places.      On 5 November, Mogilev became the first city in Belarus to introduce compulsory use of facial masks in public places.    On 9 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Gomel Region.    According to the 11 November Ministry of Health decree, PCR-based tests were no longer conducted for first-level contacts with an asymptomatic infection course.    On 12 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Minsk. As of date, besides Minsk, Gomel Region and Mogilev, such measure was reported to had been employed in Babruisk, Asipovichy, Klichev, Krichev, Chavusy District, Cherykaw District, Polotsk District and Novopolotsk.    On 16 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Vitebsk Region.    On 18 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Brest Region.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
